cmCourseInfo.description: Offers an introduction to North American cities and urbanization in a global context. It explores social, cultural, political and economic forces, processes, and events that shape contemporary urbanism. The course adopts the lens of 'fixity' and 'flow' to examine how the movement of people, ideas, goods, and capital, as well as their containment in the infrastructure and space of the city, give rise to particular urban forms.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cities and Urban Life

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, hybrid course with synchronous and asynchronous elements. Lectures will be given as two 1.5hr online videos/week synchronously, and will include discussions and interaction; recordings will be made for optional asynchronous viewing. Students will have synchronous online tutorials 1 hr/week, and an asynchronous discussion board. Students need Power Point, a word processing program for writing assignments that will be submitted online, and the ability to connect to Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra) for synchronous online class time.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the principles of geomorphology; earth materials; major features of crustal morphology; landforming processes of water, wind, waves and ice; human impact on earth surface processes. One hour laboratory session approximately every other week; a local field trip.
cmCourseInfo.title: Geomorphology

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

cmCourseInfo.description: Considers the role of planning in shaping the urban landscape through historical and contemporary examples that illustrate the interplay of modernist and post-modernist approaches to city building. Traces the origins, competing rationalities and lingering effects of planning in the production of urban space. Broaches possibilities for engaging planning critically to address challenges of social and environmental justice in cities today.
cmCourseInfo.title: Urban Landscapes and Planning

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online hybrid course. Lectures will be delivered live weekly (M-W 2-4pm) with portions dedicated for participation and discussion. Recordings of the lectures only (no discussion) will be made available afterwards for those unable to attend during class time. Tutorials (when applicable) will follow the same principle. Students need to be able to prepare and submit short essays in PDF, word or equivalent format onto Quercus and have the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: Social and economic differences have been, and continue to be, a prominent feature of Canada’s geography. In this course these differences are examined at a regional and local scale. The course adopts a thematic approach and considers issues such as historical development, urbanization, industrialization, immigration and population change, Canada’s cultural mosaic and native issues. Emphasis will be placed on the evolution of social and economic policies and Canada’s incorporation into a global economy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Geography of Canada

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This is an online synchronous course that will permit asynchronous learning after live lectures. Lectures will be given as online video streams. These lectures will occur twice a week (Tuesday and Thursday) from 14h00-16h00 EST. Recordings of these lectures will be posted on the course website after the stream. Students will have 2 opportunities for synchronous questions and clarifications. The first option will be during the live lecture. The second option will be during Wednesday and Friday, from 08h00-09h00 EST through an online webinar class/office hour. Students will need to use PowerPoint and the Blackboard Collaborate function through the Quercus-based course website.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to digital mapping and spatial analysis using geographic information systems (GIS). Students learn how to use GIS software to find, edit, analyze and map geographic data to create their own maps, analyze geographic problems and use techniques that can be applied to a variety of subject areas.
cmCourseInfo.title: Geographic Information and Mapping I

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, hybrid course. Synchronous lectures will be given from 10am-12pm on Tuesday and Thursday, students will have the opportunity for synchronous online discussion and questions during class times. These lectures will be recorded and posted online allowing for asynchronous viewing. There will also be synchronous online help desk (lab sessions) at various times throughout the week, which are optional but provide an excellent opportunity for student to obtain help from the teaching assistant. Students need to obtain a student copy of ArcGIS from the map and data library for their own PC or can work with citrix to use ArcGIS. You need to be able to work with ArcGIS on your own computer to complete this course as no lab computers will be available on campus.

cmCourseInfo.description: A comprehensive examination of the greenhouse warming problem, beginning with economic, carbon cycle, and climate model projections; impacts on and adaptive responses of agriculture, forests, fisheries, and water resources; options and policies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Global Warming

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, predominantly asynchronous, course. Modules specific to course topics will be made available on Quercus every Monday at 12:00 am (EST); these modules will contain videos, readings, and activities that students are expected to complete by the end of the week. Completion of these materials should take around 4 hours each week, on top of textbook readings and graded assessments. Tutorial readings are assigned to a particular week and students are expected to submit discussion posts each week; completing tutorial requirements should take no more than an hour each week. Office hours will be synchronous online webinars held 2 hours per week (Tuesdays and Fridays, 10:00 am – 10:30 am (EST) and 06:00 pm – 06:30 pm (EST)) for questions and clarifications regarding course topics, tutorials, and assessments. Students need constant access to Quercus to peruse the online materials and additional educational technologies such as Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

courses.name: Geographies of Transnationalism, Migration, and Gender

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines recent changes in global migration processes. Specifically, the course addresses the transnationalization and feminization of migrant populations and various segments of the global labor force. The coursework focuses on analyzing classical paradigms in migration studies, as well as emerging theoretical approaches to gender and migration. In addition, it traces the shifting empirical trends in gendered employment and mobility patterns. It uses in-depth case study material to query the frameworks employed in migration studies and to understand the grounded implications of gendered migration. It pays particular attention to the interventions made by feminist geographers in debates about work, migration, place, and space.
cmCourseInfo.title: Geographies of Transnationalism, Migration, and Gender

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, hybrid course.
Lectures will be given as 2-4hr online videos/week synchronously, with recordings made for asynchronous viewing.
Students will have synchronous online tutorials 1 hr/week and an asynchronous discussion board.
Students need Power Point, a word processor, and the ability to connect to Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra) for synchronous online class time.

courses.name: Urban Geography, Planning and Political Processes

cmCourseInfo.description: Investigates North American urban political geography, exploring conflicts over immigration, environment, gentrification, homelessness, labour market restructuring, ‘race’ and racism, urban sprawl, nature and environment, gender, sexuality, security, and segregation. Explores competing visions of city life and claims on urban space. The course investigates how these struggles connect to economic, social and environmental politics at larger spatial scales, and considers different theoretical frameworks that geographers have developed to make sense of both the persistence of old problems and the emergence of new ones. Field trip cost: $20.
cmCourseInfo.title: Urban Geography, Planning and Political Processes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures will be given as 2-3hr online videos/week asynchronously. Students will have the opportunity to attend an optional synchronous online webinar class 1hr per week (Thursdays 4-5pm) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and assignment content. Students need Power Point and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: An exploration of the aspects of health in which place or location matters. Particular attention will be paid to the role of environments (physical, social, etc.) in explaining differences in health between places, the structuring of health-related behaviour in place, and the development of health policy for places.
cmCourseInfo.title: Health Geography
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: 8.0 FCE's including one of GGR222H1/GGR223H1 or ENV236H1/JGE236H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
GGR340 is an online, asynchronous course. There will be no required live components. Lectures will be given as two x 2 hr online videos/week asynchronously. Live captioning and image descriptions can be made available upon request. Students will have the opportunity for on-demand live meetings to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and assessment content if needed. Students need Power Point and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to field studies in environmental geography. The course may include individual assignments and group work. Field trips are concentrated during a one-week period in late August or early September. Some preparation during the preceding summer may be required. Periodic course meetings and shorter field trips continue, along with course work, during the Fall Term. Each student is required to pay the costs of their transportation and accommodation (field trip costs: $100). Students must register with the Department by April. Course may be limited by size. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Field Course in Environmental Geography
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: 10.0 FCE's including 3.0 FCE's in Geography (SOC SCI/BR=3)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
The field trips will happen on Fridays during the lecture and tutorial time-slots. An application will be available before the end of February at https://geography.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/experiential-learning/ A background in Environmental Geography or Environmental studies is necessary.
